title: Acute Cholangitis
diagnosis_topic: Ascending infection of the biliary tree secondary to obstruction
setup_script: A 60-year-old man presents with fever, jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. He has a history of gallstones but no prior surgeries.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 95/55 mmHg, HR 118 bpm, RR 22/min, Temp 39 C, SpO2 95%.
Icteric sclera, right upper quadrant tenderness; may have hypotension and confusion (Reynolds pentad).
Elevated WBC 18 K/uL, bilirubin 5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 300 U/L, AST/ALT mildly elevated.
Dilated common bile duct with gallstones; gallbladder with stones but no wall thickening.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts aggressive IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident consults gastroenterology for emergent ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography performed to decompress the bile duct and remove the obstructing stone.
Consider percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage or surgical exploration.
Patient develops septic shock and multiple organ failure.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses Charcot's triad and Reynolds pentad
dynamic_flow.reply: Fever, jaundice and RUQ pain; pentad adds hypotension and mental status changes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses timing of cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Interval cholecystectomy performed after resolution of cholangitis to prevent recurrence.
Monitor for post-ERCP pancreatitis; continue antibiotics until sepsis resolves.
Discuss lifestyle changes and gallstone prevention.

critical_decision_points: Identification of acute cholangitis and recognition of Charcot's triad/Reynolds pentad
Initial resuscitation with fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Urgent biliary decompression via ERCP or alternative methods
Avoiding delays that lead to sepsis and organ failure
Planning interval cholecystectomy and patient education
